I have included a debunking of 'accumulated heat' as it is so often used to explain how trace elements, so called 'greenhouse gasses', can warm the planet.

Accumulated heat whilst sounding a reasonable explanation of how heat can build up is rather nothing more than gobbledygook. In fact it shows those using such arguments do not even understand what heat is.

When we measure temperature we are measuring the heat energy a thing is losing. In short heat is a measurement of flow, the transfer of heat energy and this will always be in the direction towards the colder. For this reason a thing can never 'accumulate heat' in the way those advocating CO2 climate change describe. The temperature of a body is the measure of heat output, it can never be greater than the measure of heat input. Output = input. When a thing is warmed it is heated to an equivalent of the heat input. If this input is not maintained it will cool. Those that propose that heat can build up to be hotter than the total measure of heat input at a given time either do not understand what heat is or are being deliberately misleading. To illustrate, an object being heated by a flame can never become hotter than that flame, it's temperature cannot rise inexorably to the temperature of the sun for instance. Heat cannot be accumulated. When we think about it common sense tells us this must be the case.

NASA and even Nobel Prize winning physicists have expounded 'accumulated heat' as the explanation how CO2 is able to warm the atmosphere. They claim that over hundreds of years CO2 has captured heat energy and this heat has 'accumulated' to produce a serious warming effect. As I have just explained, this is totally impossible and fundamentally violates all the laws of thermodynamics. That respected scientists should support such uneducated, unthinking nonsense is disturbing and only reflects that in terms of being able to think clearly about a subject they have no facility or inclination. These are the Dark Ages of science. Belief has outweighed logic or any critical thought. It tells us that we should not unquestioningly accept anything we are told, that experts can be fools.

(NB: be aware of attempts to discard thermodynamics by talking about biology.
Eg. 'It only takes a drop of arsenic to kill a person.'
This would be somewhat desperate, muddled thinking. Clearly biological processes based on the reaction of a cell are not the same as the laws of physics/thermodynamics).

Attention all Climate Change deniers....We just went through the hottest heat wave that Canada 🇨🇦 has ever experienced.  I am presently visiting Kelowna, BC and experienced 45C. A lady that I have known for 40 years and worked with for 20 years who lives down here now weathered the heat wave with me.  She brought her portable AC and with 3 AC's going and 5 fans we managed with lots of lemon water.  Just barely, I might add.  I had to put up strips of aluminum foil up behind some of the blinds on our closed in balcony and when I accidentally touched the glass of one of the windows it burned like an oven door.  Horrible experience.
Kelowna is more or less prepared for the heat but Vancouver, Canada is not....hundreds of people died sudden deaths attributed to the extreme heat.  There was a small town, Lytton, BC , 🇨🇦 that experienced the hottest temperature 49.6C that was ever been experienced in Canada and then abruptly experienced wildfire and burned to the ground.  The towns people barely escaped with their lives and an elderly couple died in the fire.  The biggest part of the Okanagan BC cherry crop has cooked on the trees so most of it is lost.  A lot of apples are now little bags of apple sauce on the trees and out on the coast at least a billion shallow water sea creatures also cooked and now smell to high heaven. 
Southern Yukon and Whitehorse and Carmacks are presently under flood warnings and Canadian soldiers have been deployed to Yukon to help.
How much more of this does the world have to see before serious action is taken?  I personally think that it is too late for much to be done now other than remedial action such as aggressive local Government fire smarting, flood smarting and aggressive Community Action such as Community food gardens and everyone turn what ground they have into food gardens such as the " Victory Gardens" in England during WW2.  My husband and I have planted what we can get to grow at our place...potatoes that we hope to pair with Moose meat. my husband nd his 82 year old hunting partner and friend of over 40 years ( who has also planted potatoes and will share with us if need be) have planned to go moose hunting again this year and hopefully bring one back to go with our potatoes like last year.  My youngest son and his daughter will most certainly go Bison hunting again this year and hopefully get a bison.  My Granddaughter is also going on a school Bison hunt this winter Covid allowing and I think she is the designated shooter. 
It has finally cooled down in Kelowna...for a day at least...then back to the usual 30's of an Okanagan Summer today according to Environment lCanada. However, 31 is a lot better than 45 let me tell you.
All that said, get on it you slackers!!!

I've been looking into the maths of this subject for a while now. This is what I've found.

The Earth's Greenhouse effect of 34C is entirely a product of assuming the energy balance applies at the surface. The immediate question is why do we assume sea level is the correct surface? Why not include the sea bed, the average altitude of dry land, the tropopause or the clouds? All of these could arguably be a "surface".

Yet if we look at every world in the solar system that has an atmosphere we don't find a balance at 1 bar of pressure (Earth sea level pressure) anywhere. It is always higher up than that. The closest match is the top of the main cloud systems. Perhaps that represents the effective reach of atmospheric circulation for this problem.

The actual temperature balance for Earth is at about 5km up which is roughly consistent with the above. What this means is that the actual Greenhouse effect is much smaller than 34C. My hunch is that its in the bottom third of that range, 10C to 0C. That's right, it might be that it is actually zero and this whole business is based on applying the equations at the wrong altitude.

The temperature at any other altitude is then due to the lapse rate which is simply the normal temperature gradient you get going up or down through the atmosphere.

I have noticed that CO2 tends to emit radiation higher up the atmosphere but that does not mean heat lower down is "trapped". Also we don't know what the actual relationship between CO2 and temperature is, it is very difficult to claim that either one causes the other.

What about the graphs that show runaway rising temperatures? If you look at the sources they nearly always quote Marcott and Hadcrut. These are different, one is low frequency so it does not include decades long warming, the other is high frequency so it does. The main reason the graphs look different is that they represent different methods of dealing with the data.

Other graphs of past temperatures exist and they show a range of results. Alley and Mann for example show previous warm periods that look very like ours.

Overall it looks is if there are good reasons to doubt the doomsday messages and also to doubt large parts of the science, or to be more accurate the assumptions behind it and the way it is presented to us.

Hey man. I'm center-right in ideological worldview. I am an individualist, I hate the government, and I think supporting corporations is important because 90% of corporarions are small businesses and people working tirelessly to build up their own part of the world is incredible and needs to be supported.

All of that said, I believe in climate change and think something needs to be done about it. However, when folks left of center try to have this conversation - they often assume the only solution is through the government. This is dangerous and shuts down dialogue. Scientific consensus on the issue of climate change =/= consensus on policy prescription. I find a lot of the time that people left of center will call folks client change deniers when they do not believe a carbon tax will work, but do believe climate change is a problem that needs to be addressed now. This is harmful to the discussion from your side of the isle. When discussing ideological "poisoning of the well" - the left has a huge blind spot in the tactics that they use to do the same types of things they disdain in the right.

Personally, I think that technological innovation will bring us out of this. If enough businesses have the funds and resources for R&D, then they will have an economic incentive to develop something that tackles this issue. I think that slapping a carbon tax on the industry might delay the effects of climate change, but ultimately prohibit it from being resolved in a timely manner - which is what we all want, right? If we extend the duration of a solution, it might not come about in time. It's like placing a bandaid on a slit throat. We need to figure out a way to stitch the artery now - not waste time with the bandaid. Taking money out of the pockets of people who can actually develop that technology right now is a net negative, imo.

I think the left has a tendency to focus in on the bad apples in the group. The Bill and Melinda Gates foundation wouldn't exist with the policies y'all push. I also find that the policies don't accomplish the things you hope that they do. People on the left have this disdain for large corporations, but then place their hope in the largest, most corrupt monopolistic enterprise that has ever existed - the government. It makes no sense to me.

To clarify this point - people become cynical when you present a crisis and imply you know the solution's correct policy prescription when presenting scientific facts. It's hard for some people to accept that this isn't just another tactic to increase taxes.

I don't believe in Man Made Climate Change but I liked this video, would be great to have discussions with people on this without being attacked, personally I would add:
1) Don't say "the science is settled", science is about constantly challenging assumptions and re-testing hypotheses when new information becomes available. We have been studying the human body for 100's of years and are still unsure whether saturated fat is good or bad for you, the climate involves infinitely more complex systems and integration of different scientific disciplines yet you think this particular area has been "settled"?? We're still arguing about the number of planets in our solar system, the number of elements on the periodic table... The politicians and news people are the ones who say the science is settled, the Bill Nyes of this world, not the scientists themselves.
2) Don't say "99% of scientists agree!" - those studies have been proven massively inaccurate with scientists actually voicing that their studies had been misrepresented. The authors often mis-allocated studies which merely talked about the consequences of climate change IF it happened as studies which PROVED climate change was real - yet studies of this caliber pass peer review?
3) Speaking of sea-levels, don't say X million people will be living under sea-level, especially without knowing that X million people already live below sea-level... and definitely don't say "but the sea-levels will rise by X meters" because that's wrong - nearly the entire mass of an the earth's ice is below sea-level already so it wont have any effect, and any amount that is above sea-level will be almost exactly equal to the decrease in volume which occurs when ice turns to water.

Dr. Mann's Penn State Hockey stick climate graph took off in the 1980's, which indicated global warming. But I moved near a Penn State branch campus in 1981. I first noticed that the climatology weather station was in the corner of a parking lot, as far from the buildings and cars as possible, and surrounded on 3 sides by a meadow.  It seemed to me the best place for such a weather station -- as far from the buildings and cars as possible.  The next year, however, they moved the climate station to the middle of the parking lot, next to a big building, and directly underneath a big air conditioning exhaust far.  At the time, I simply thought that the temperature readings might be a few degrees warmer now, but the students could dash outside without their coats, write down some data on their clipboards, and go back inside in the winter.  What if they moved the climate stations to a warmer spot at all 20 Penn State campuses across the state?

I''ll probably never believe in global warming for no over reason but lack of data. Particularly, if we had a longer temperature record and measured on todays standards, as well as a longer co2 record to confirm the correlation with more certainty.  But when the official temp record began, it only covered 20% of the globe and mostly in the northern hemi. In modern times 80% of the globe is covered and they are working on further improvement. So, for much of the accepted record that shows warming, much of the globe wasn't even covered. You don't have to be an expert scientist to have reasonable doubts about the temperature record. And it would be nice if they had started measuring co2 a long time before the official temp record, so we could see a clear and long official measured co2 behaviour pre-industrialisation and the human factor at play at the point of industrialisation. But unfortunately, because of alarmism, people aren't willing to wait for real data that won't be avaliable for decades, or even centuries to come.  With a branch of science (climate science) that can't even do a controlled experiment to back up its primary claim i.e. that anthropogenic co2 causes the warming,  they shouldn't be making the claims of certainty and alarmism they do without the hard data at hand. That doesn't mean we shouldn't  do things to reduce pollution,  do scientific research and innovation for alternative energy sources,, and protect natural sinks, clean up the ocean etc, but it does mean we should not be rushing the west into urgent social and economic structural change and that we should be recognising a developing nations right to use its natural resources in a way to develop on similar terms to us. I went to a private Christian school for all of elementary and middle school, and when I was about 11 or 12, a lecturer came to our school and talked about how climate change wasn’t real and that it was just a natural progression of the cycle of the earth. He showed a lot of data, and my parents aren’t climate change deniers per say, but they also don’t feel strongly that we need to do anything to protect the earth so they didn’t set me straight. The lecturer also taught about a 6000 year old earth and stuff like that. I firmly believed everything he said until I got to college. By then, I was starting to doubt some of what he said and was ready to hear about what other people’s opinions of these things was. Luckily, I had a few professors who set me straight, and I got to do some projects for different classes that forced me to do research. I’m glad now I know the facts about climate change and other things I was taught as a young child that I no longer believe. I am still a Christian, but I don’t put on blinders and think that humanity was meant to destroy the earth in the way we have. I believe good stewardship of what God has given to humanity is to take care of it and preserve it. However, as someone who used to believe all of climate change was a hoax, I understand the arguments they make and how hard it can be to change someone’s mind.

The debate that asks the question "is the global climate changing" is over. The global climate is changing, but the actual question of whether or not man's industrial and fossil fuel burning activities have contributed towards 'causing' the global climate to undergo the changes we are now experiencing is not an easy question to answer, but I think the evidence does point towards them doing so.

We have been burning fossil fuels intensely since the dawn of the industrial revolution almost 300 years ago, and over that period of time, we have increased our CO2 production exponentially year on year, especially as other countries began their own industrial revolution. We have not stopped increasing our CO2 production with each passing year. All that CO2 is not from natural occurrences, but from man's manufactured occurrences. All of it is 'extra' to natural phases of CO2 production, so of course, it cannot be denied that we have contributed (300 years worth) to the current levels of CO2.

With having so much CO2 around, the earth's natural carbon sinks are quite saturated and are unable to take in CO2 at levels that make much of a difference, so more CO2 is in the atmosphere than what is normally present. This warms the air, and along with the sun's constant solar radiation, the energy in the atmosphere increases which leads to more intense weather systems propagating stronger storms and greater precipitation, especially in areas where the climate tends to be more 'moderate'. What we are experiencing and witnessing today are changes to local weather systems that normally worked pretty clock-work like, that were stable and moderate within a fine-tuning. It is the fine-tuning that is breaking down, and is the first symptom of climate change.

I predict that as the atmosphere warms further, leading to greater land ice melting and finding its way into the sea, not only will there be loss of coastal regions as the seas rise, but we should be able to detect the sea rises at geographical places where the seas are channelled (bottle-necked) between landmasses, rises in sea levels will be focused at these points around the world first. Sea level rises will lead to greater amounts of precipitation over land masses, where more frequent flooding will be experienced each year.

You can argue all you want about causes of climate change, but the fact is...it is happening, and it will only become more intense. If the industrial revolution had never occurred, there would not be 300 years worth of 'extra' CO2 in the natural carbon sinks and atmosphere.

If there is one statement that really pisses me off is the 'we have to save the planet' bullshit. We are not saving the planet, we are looking to save the environments of our current habitats from being overwhelmed by events rapid in their occurrence. We can deal with slow catastrophic events, and also catastrophic events that occur in small local regions, but fast, wider-ranging events can knock us for six, and put great stressors upon our social and technological infrastructures. Just bear in mind that our greatest fragility is being dependent on electricity always available at the press of a switch, and that means that every single one of us who have commented on this thread could not handle the loss of electricity for up to just six months, let alone it disappearing forever.

Climate change is a hoax. It's funny when people talk about "the overwhelming scientific consensus", and yet they don't know a damn thing about the science. 1) The earth has been continually warming since the end of the Little Ice Age in 1850. This predates the invention of the internal combustion engine. 2) Atmospheric CO2 does not heat the atmosphere in a linear fashion, but rather logarithmically. If doubling CO2 causes 2 degrees higher temperatures, then you'd have to quadruple CO2 to get 2 more degrees higher temperatures. Ice core samples show that atmospheric CO2 has been as high as 8000ppm, and yet everything was fine. 3) Global temperatures and atmospheric CO2 is not highly correlated. In earth's past temperatures have gone down as CO2 went up and vice versa. The evidence shows that CO2 actually follows global temperatures, so it would be more correct to say that higher global temperatures causes higher CO2, rather than the other way around. 4) It was warmer during the Middle Ages than it is now. Historically, the earth has been much warmer, and we're in one of the coldest periods of the Holocene (the last 11,000 years of earth's history).

As a very nostalgic teenager, there are a couple of things that would have reached me. The first is a tragic country song comparing the earth to a woman who is ravaged and destroyed. The second is a Terry Tempest Williams book, and anything similar to that. I didn't need a man being angry or condemnatory or acting smarter than me. I needed a wise, kind woman who could help me feel that being a woman is a good thing. I needed a woman to show me how to do an adult version of the spiritual connection to the earth I saw in Pocahontas. I needed a man (specifically a cowboy or conservative religious man) to regret his greed and control over the earth and women.

Imagine for a while that you are someone else. Here is your alternative life history (which was actually mine). At five years old, you liked getting up early to watch captain planet. You liked your Pocahontas shirt. You felt safe and spiritual listening to the wise Grandmother Willow and the Colors of the Wind song. You felt guilty for liking these things because your parents disapproved of environmentalism. Your mom read an article against global warming while watching your swim lessons. You began homeschooling at age 10. Your last year of public school science was fourth grade. You were a very ill child who found it difficult to learn. You don't remember doing science in fifth grade. At the end of sixth grade you read an Abeka science book on your own. Abeka is a very conservative Christian homeschool curriculum company. You tried to go to public school part time in seventh grade but it didn't work out. You had one semester of science, which taught about electrical circuits, not climate. You used a Creationist book for eighth grade science. The whole book argued against evolution. You didn't do science after that. You learned that science wasn't interesting, and being interested in it would probably create unnecessary conflict with your parents that you didn't have the energy for and besides, you'd always been the obedient oldest child. If you didn't have your parents on your side with your health problems, you were going to be our of luck. You went to community college. You walked into an English class where the teacher announced "Welcome to Environmental English." You were scared. You were probably going to be attacked or made to feel stupid by some angry liberals. Your teacher turns out to be one of the best you've ever had before or since. He calmly teaches you how to read arguments about which power production technologies to use where. He wants you to learn to think. Maybe liberals aren't so bad after all. You still put off biology as long as possible. You transfer from there to a conservative religious university which thankfully still teaches evolution even though many in the religion don't believe in it. You walk into Intro Biology for non-science majors. You were among many students who didn't know that evolution was real. The teacher sucks, but the one lecture where he held up models of skills demonstrating ape to human evolution was neat. It makes you want to learn more later. Years pass. You de-convert from your religion. You start to wonder about science. What about it might be true and interesting, or the opposite. You hear people who probably grew up knowing things you didn't getting frustrated with people like you. You feel put in the middle of a fight between the people you came from and the people you're starting to tentatively like. If you were me, what would you do? How would you like to be spoken to, at various stages of my life? If you've read all this, you deserve a gold star and a coffee.

When I have similar conversations I find you never win in the moment and you usually find that the other party gets more entrenched in their mindset at least for the moment. However I do find that you can make some success by planting seeds that beat climate change denial at its own game (success judged by change in opinion in follow up conversations).

For instance when I hear that it is too expensive to subsidize green tech and infrastructure I point out that we already heavily subsidize oil production here in Canada and that oil is one of the most capital intensive, labour non intensive industries out there and that it needs to be that way for the companies to keep up the way they have been (for those of you who work in the Alberta oil sands, how much money goes into just the purchase of the heavy mining equipment that was built in other countries vs your annual salary). I contrast this with the amount of Human Resources go into creating a windmill or a solar panel where the labour costs are a significantly higher proportion of the final cost of the product. Labour cost equals jobs and jobs equal families with a wage to live off of.

Or for people who don’t trust the government. I point out that most researchers work for private companies or universities and that the vast majority of green tech development is being done by private entities. The government just thinks it’s a good idea to support them, much like they have done for oil, gas, and coal.

And the most important thing that I find you can do is to listen to the other person because they probably have concerns, fears, and misconceptions just like us. It is very easy to become preachy and then nobody listens at all. At the end of the day the goal isn’t to be right, the goal is to show them that believing in the science of climate change is about wanting a good future where our energy comes from much more sustainable sources

There’s an ecological fallacy involved in this conversation.

Scientists point out data about climate trends which involve large periods of time and data-points, they inherently have to be presented as coherent stories to the public (that’s the only way we can understand them in general).

Then a deduction is made by the inference to either say that x weather event (a distinct data point) supports or invalidates climate change (the large trend of continuous data-points) by either conforming to the story or not conforming to it.

The fallacy is that we are deducing (producing something certain) from an inference (statistical likelihood). With this you can select and point to any fact and think you disproved or proved climate change.

One thing that should always be done in an argument is to immediately put yourself on the other person's level: find one thing you both agree upon, even the stupidest, stick to it and make the discussion orbit around it. I believe in climate change, but treating the opposing side like they're idiots or conflating them to mostly be conservatives is disingenuous at best and stupidly arrogant at worst. Especially since the controversy isn't whether climate change is real or not, but how much human activity is effecting it, which isn't as black and white as say, a non-flat Earth or there being two genders. Just in case you wanted to know why I and others hit Dislike.

Even Skepticalscience.com has it's skeptics. I do not want to push an agenda for or against climate change. I disagree partly with the human activity portion. While I agree that we do play a role changes in our environment, the distance our planet is from the sun is the most contributing factor to the temperature of the Earth. We do not orbit the sun in a perfect circle by any axis, in fact no two cycles are the same. These changes as skeptical science points out indeed take long periods of time, though there are times when temperatures on Earth dropped or rose significantly and abruptly. The last Ice Age lasted for 2.58 million years, and then in a span of 11,700 years thawed out to where we are today. Putting that into perspective, when we as humans think that we cause significant climate change to this planet that has been enduring consistently and constantly changing climate patterns. Of course we are more focused on how climate change effects humans and the environment and not the Earth as a whole. The fact of the matter is that even if we kill all the cows, stop all the factories, eliminate all CO2 emission, we probably wouldn't put a dent in the current climate patterns. Significant change to the planet's climate even if every single one of us adopted a green lifestyle would probably not happen before some other natural disaster. Don't hate on me or be disrespectful, I am only trying to spark a meaningful and respectful debate, because it seems to me that both sides have shaky science to throw at the other side.

Living in Saskatchewan, there is lots of ranting and roaring about how the Carbon Tax is out to destroy our jobs and punish the working man and whatnot. I always return with the fact that we live in the sunniest and windiest province in the country. We have the space and location to be at the forefront of wind and solar energy in the country. Choosing not to sell oil wholesale outside of our province is better for our economy. It also would put us on the leading edge of the energy shift, which is when companies have the greatest potential to make money. I don't know if making the executives of the oil and gas corporations the bad guys helps or not. I know people are angry about it, or at least frustrated, but it usually translates to 'if they got to make money from this industry for the last century, why shouldn't I get to?' No one likes to hear that the company they work for doesn't benefit the workers as much as the executives, but perhaps the potential of working your way up the company makes them less likely to condemn it? I really struggle with trying to understand blue collar, on the ground workers being on the same side as the highly paid upper echelons of the companies they work for.

There are so many things wrong with this video that It's difficult to know where to begin so I'll address a pet peeve issue to get things started that's repeated ad infinitum. Consensus is NOT part of the scientific method. Being able to duplicate experiments does help, agreeing with others peer reviewed work can also help but it's not how the scientific method operates and in no way concludes truth of a hypothesis.

Albert Einstein Quote: “Genius abhors consensus because when consensus is reached, thinking stops. Stop nodding your head.”

100 Authors Against Einstein - Scientific 'Consensus' and Scepticism

Why 100 authors? If I were wrong, then one would have been enough! - Albert Einstein

Consensus is utterly irrelevant to science. The philosophy of science is devoid of consensus. What concerns science is not weight of numbers on the side of an argument, but what the facts are. What the evidence is.

There was plenty of consensus that the Earth was the center of the universe.

We need to destigmatize nuclear energy.
It's not a forever alternative but it's clean, green, cheaper, more efficient, and has higher yields. The fear of nuclear "chernobyl" explosions should be put to rest. The science in cooling nuclear rods with things that block more radiation as opposed to less when it gets heated is basically the solution to positive feedback loops that cause meltdown making it impossible to reach meltdown. Finally, the nuclear waste produced by these plants can be easily contained but does exist. This is why it can't be a permanent solutions but we as a planet can contain this waste for a few decades without issue; no water pollution, air pollutants, carbon release, or nuclear runoff. This waste will be irradiated for thousands of years but as an interim solution, is the only reliable choice really. Then after solar panels that last longer than a couple years that can be built, repaired, and replaced at sensible cost, that will be a better, perhaps permanent, solution.


As an aside, I wouldn't recommend windmills. If we were to somehow wind farm for the world's energy, taking that energy from the atmosphere, that has unforeseeable effects the same way Carbon emissions does. This is a real thing btw. Wind energy isn't some infinite source. It's taking our planet's climate, reducing it's kinetic energy, and using that. On large scale, it's easy to see why that could easily be a problem.

Except there is no consensus. Unlike you, I actually looked into this. No one went around the world interviewing every scientist to get their opinion. The consensus myth is the result of two very flawed studies. One was soliciting replies from a mailing list of around 3,000 people (most of whom were not climate scientists).
In the other, the IPCC looked at an arbitrary sample of research papers to see who disagreed with their narrative. Those who disagreed were put in the disagree pile, those who agreed were put in the agree pile. And those who were silent on the IPCC's narrative (which made up more than 90% of studies) were arbitrarily added to the agree pile. This is an obvious and outrageous case of academic fraud.
You should become better informed before you talk down with that air of condescension to those who disagree with your poorly informed views. Some of us have done serious investigation of this topic rather than simply regurgitating what we are told on that juvenile IFL Science facebook page.

WE ARE NOT TO BLAME! According to the Vostok Ice Core Records, CO2 level changes have followed Earth's overall temperature changes at an 800 year lag for the last 800,000 years. That means that our current CO2 levels are the result of Earth's overall temperature 800 years ago, which coincides with the Medieval Warm Period (950-1250 CE). World leaders have convinced their dependents that this works in the reverse order, relatively quickly, and that we are to blame, so that they can tax us out of a false shared guilt in order to be able to afford to "fight" climate change, an unstoppable natural cycle. What we may need are commercial solutions that will aid in the survival of the human race throughout the coming centuries. The following is the source information for this comment:

Historical Carbon Dioxide Record from the Vostok Ice Core

Investigators
J.-M. Barnola, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius
Laboratoire de Glaciologie et de Géophysique de l'Environnement,
CNRS, BP96,
38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France

N.I. Barkov
Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute,
Beringa Street 38, 199397,
St. Petersburg, Russia

Period of Record
417,160 - 2,342 years BP

Methods
In January 1998, the collaborative ice-drilling project between Russia, the United States, and France at the Russian Vostok station in East Antarctica yielded the deepest ice core ever recovered, reaching a depth of 3,623 m (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Ice cores are unique with their entrapped air inclusions enabling direct records of past changes in atmospheric trace-gas composition. Preliminary data indicate the Vostok ice-core record extends through four climate cycles, with ice slightly older than 400 kyr (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Because air bubbles do not close at the surface of the ice sheet but only near the firn-ice transition (that is, at ~90 m below the surface at Vostok), the air extracted from the ice is younger than the surrounding ice (Barnola et al. 1991). Using semiempirical models of densification applied to past Vostok climate conditions, Barnola et al. (1991) reported that the age difference between air and ice may be ~6000 years during the coldest periods instead of ~4000 years, as previously assumed. Ice samples were cut with a bandsaw in a cold room (at about -15°C) as close as possible to the center of the core in order to avoid surface contamination (Barnola et al. 1983). Gas extraction and measurements were performed with the "Grenoble analytical setup," which involved crushing the ice sample (~40 g) under vacuum in a stainless-steel container without melting it, expanding the gas released during the crushing in a pre-evacuated sampling loop, and analyzing the CO2 concentrations by gas chromatography (Barnola et al. 1983). The analytical system, except for the stainless-steel container in which the ice was crushed, was calibrated for each ice sample measurement with a standard mixture of CO2 in nitrogen and oxygen. For further details on the experimental procedures and the dating of the successive ice layers at Vostok, see Barnola et al. (1987, 1991), Lorius et al. (1985), and Petit et al. (1999).

Trends
There is a close correlation between Antarctic temperature and atmospheric concentrations of CO2 (Barnola et al. 1987). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows that the main trends of CO2 are similar for each glacial cycle. Major transitions from the lowest to the highest values are associated with glacial-interglacial transitions. During these transitions, the atmospheric concentrations of CO2 rises from 180 to 280-300 ppmv (Petit et al. 1999). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows the present-day levels of CO2 are unprecedented during the past 420 kyr. Pre-industrial Holocene levels (~280 ppmv) are found during all interglacials, with the highest values (~300 ppmv) found approximately 323 kyr BP. When the Vostok ice core data were compared with other ice core data (Delmas et al. 1980; Neftel et al. 1982) for the past 30,000 - 40,000 years, good agreement was found between the records: all show low CO2 values [~200 parts per million by volume (ppmv)] during the Last Glacial Maximum and increased atmospheric CO2 concentrations associated with the glacial-Holocene transition. According to Barnola et al. (1991) and Petit et al. (1999) these measurements indicate that, at the beginning of the deglaciations, the CO2 increase either was in phase or lagged by less than ~1000 years with respect to the Antarctic temperature, whereas it clearly lagged behind the temperature at the onset of the glaciations.

References
Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, A. Neftel, and H. Oeschger. 1983. Comparison of CO2 measurements by two laboratories on air from bubbles in polar ice. Nature 303:410-13.

Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, Y.S. Korotkevich, and C. Lorius. 1987. Vostok ice core provides 160,000-year record of atmospheric CO2. Nature 329:408-14.

Barnola, J.-M., P. Pimienta, D. Raynaud, and Y.S. Korotkevich. 1991. CO2-climate relationship as deduced from the Vostok ice core: A re-examination based on new measurements and on a re-evaluation of the air dating. Tellus 43(B):83- 90.

Delmas, R.J., J.-M. Ascencio, and M. Legrand. 1980. Polar ice evidence that atmospheric CO2 20,000 yr BP was 50% of present. Nature 284:155-57.

Jouzel, J., C. Lorius, J.R. Petit, C. Genthon, N.I. Barkov, V.M. Kotlyakov, and V.M. Petrov. 1987. Vostok ice core: A continuous isotopic temperature record over the last climatic cycle (160,000 years). Nature 329:403-8.

Lorius, C., J. Jouzel, C. Ritz, L. Merlivat, N.I. Barkov, Y.S. Korotkevich, and V.M. Kotlyakov. 1985. A 150,000-year climatic record from Antarctic ice. Nature 316:591-96.

Pépin, C. Ritz, E. Saltzman, and M. Stievenard. 1999. Climate and atmospheric history of the past 420,000 years from the Vostok ice core, Antarctica. Nature 399: 429-436.

I do not deny that the climate is changing. I cannot deny that the world is getting warmer, the facts show it. I do, however, believe the cause is not squarely on the shoulders of mankind. I do not deny that we are terrible to our planet, but I also do not believe that our factories and CO2 emissions can have the effect that the climate change people say it is having. When a burp from a volcano belches out more CO2 in a single event than mankind and factories belch out over multiple years, I don't believe we're solely to blame. I like facts.


For instance, out of all the greenhouse gasses in our atmosphere, only 3.62% is CO2. And out of that 3.62% of greenhouse gasses that are CO2, only 3.4% of that is caused by humans. (source: http://burtrutan.com/downloads/EngrCritiqueCAGW-v4o3.pdf)


Remember that correlation does not imply causation. The industrial revolution may coincide with our measurements of the climate change, but that could be because it was due to the technology that we got better at recording data. The world is getting hotter, by temperature readings across the planet. However, MANY of those temperature systems are built in cities and at airports; places paved and notorious for heat. With the bias for recording temperatures in developed areas, it skews our data. Especially when NASA reported in 2014 that the Antarctic sea ice reached a new record maximum. (source: https://www.nasa.gov/content/goddard/antarctic-sea-ice-reaches-new-record-maximum).



How could the ice sheet reach a new record maximum if the planet is getting warmer due to human involvement in the middle of our climate catastrophe? because our readings are skewed by being taken where streets are paved and jet exhaust heats up the tarmac? I'll say it again: Correlation does not imply causation. I do not deny that the climate is changing, I do deny that we are the cause.


Finally, if humans are to blame for climate change, how come other planets are going through climate change as well? Mars is getting hotter, is our impact on earth affecting the weather on mars? (source: https://www.space.com/33001-mars-ice-age-ending-now.html).


In conclusion, the facts show that climate change is real, but the facts do not support the position that humans are to blame.

From a certain economic point of view, climate change is not best solved by government intervention. It's not (necessarily) that they genuinely disbelieve in science, but that they distrust the effects of large government action. The primary focus is the inefficiency of bureaucracies.
So, one has to imagine a scenario where an individualistic, market-driven solution to climate change is presented. A general problem with this is that alternative energy sources are usually less efficient. This is where I introduce the topic of nuclear energy.

In a way, my strongest argument when faced with someone of a more right-leaning political orientation is the my belief that public perception of nuclear energy harms economic growth, which is of course common ground with individualistic, market-oriented thinkers. If you don't agree with me on the question of nuclear power, there are similar issues, such as hydro-electric dams. These dams suffer the same public perception issues, and thus government regulation issues, as nuclear power, and serve as an effective tool to combat climate change.

Essentially the advice I'm giving is to show that some of the possible solutions may align with their views, even if you might politically oppose those solutions.

There really is a crisis here. It's the lack of ability to accept information that contradicts preconceived beliefs. In terms of Climate Change science, even scientists are vulnerable to this. If someone comes up to you with information that essentially invalidates all your life's work and every degree you've handed out as a professor, you tend to reject it out right even if that information is solid and grounded in facts. The biggest problem with consensus science is that it makes it possible for vast number of scientists to fall victim to the same underlying flaws of that consensus, while simultaneously giving the hypothesis as a whole a sense of truth without actually being true. 'All these scientists say it's true, so it must be.' right? This isn't logistical thinking at all. History proves that it only takes one person to get something right, and it is often the majority who find themselves on the side of denial. This is why Galileo had such a hard time convincing everyone the world was round and not flat despite him having all the evidence he needed in his notes and in the view of his telescope. They had a consensus that they refused to let go of until the evidence was just to overwhelming.
This time we find ourselves in that same situation, only now it's about how climate changes. That facts are that we do need to regulate emissions and clean the environment. The facts are also that consensus scientists have fallen victim to a fatal flaw in their work that effectively makes every paper, book, study, and model void and invalid because they all share the same foundation. There is more on this here if you want to better understand our climate and the situation we really face as a species:

Copied from me answering someone how "CO2 causes climate change?"

Heat radiates from the sun, which warms the earth. both CO2 and the Earth's surface reflect that radiation back into space, absorbing a little bit whenever it reflects, which we feel as heat. If you imagine the sun's radiation as 100 rays of light at 100% power, and every time they reflect they lose one tenth their power (really simplifying it here), if we had no CO2 in the atmosphere it'd reflect all off the surface once and we'd absorb 10% of the radiation of all 100 rays and as heat and the other 90% of all 100 rays would bounce back into space. If the earth was half covered in CO2, 50 rays would bounce back into space immediately and the other 50 would bounce back off the surface. The heating comes because of the 50 that hit the earth, only 25 will bounce back into space, the other 25 will hit the CO2 again, bouncing back to earth, then 12.5 into space and 12.5 on the CO2, etc., and by the end both the surface and the CO2 have absorbed much of the ray's energy because they keep bouncing back and forth trapped within our atmosphere. It's like that old brick breaker game, if you trap the ball between layers of bricks, you destroy a lot more, except instead of bricks it's CO2 and the Surface and instead of the ball it's radiation.

Well, from my own experience, a lot of people think that science tells us that human activity is not responsible for the climate change. They usually talks about "natural cycles", sun activity, and so on.
They even have articles (pseudo-scientific articles) to "prove" their point. The only way to convince those people, imo, is to demonstrate them, one data point at a time, how their source of information twists the facts or hides important informations. Those peope are like you and me: they don't like being lied to.
It's generally a long work, not fun to do, and sometimes you have to work hard on yourself not to loose your temper when they start calling you names or acting smug.

Also, we definitively need to learn how to have an epistemic interview. Have a look at the work of Anthony Magnabosco. Listen, ask questions, let them take their time to think. Most of times, your goal shouldn't be to convince people, but just to shatter a bit their beliefs, bring them a bit of doubt and the tools to start rethinking their point of view. And then, let them do the rest of the work themselves. And try to be nice. Don't start this if you won't be to able stay nice, calm and patient.

Oh, and never start that kind of conversation in public. One to one "debate" is better, because nobody will feel judged by others, you won't feel the need to show the "audience" that you're right. So you both will be less inclined to be on the defensive.

The first thing to do in science, including social science, is to define your terms. Not 'know your audience' so you can do effective PR, but know your subject so you're not making dishonest propaganda with your PR. 'Climate change denier' is undefined, but used for PR to defame. Its usage includes literally opposite things, from people who deny there is global warming, all the way over to people who think it is real and urgent, who oppose the policies of what is effectively the officially sanctioned green movement, which that movement itself declares are ineffective and insufficient, and support instead the only serious measures -- geoengineering and nuclear energy - to combat global warming. And everything in-between, which runs a vast range, including real scientists who try to clarify the known facts and the state of science and predictive probabilities about global warming and correct the simplistic PR versions that are being massively broadcast on that subject.
